sen.j: 茶碗（ちゃわん）とは、元々は磁器で作られた喫茶のための食器。
sen.e: Chawan originally referred to a porcelain bowl made for drinking tea.
Chawan originally referred to a porcelain bowl made for drinking tea.
Chawan originally referred to a porcelain bowl made for drinking tea.

sen.j: 喫茶の普及と共に「茶碗」という言葉も広まり、喫茶用途以外の磁器も指す磁器の代名詞として使われた。
sen.e: Along with the spread of tea drinking habit, the word 'chawan' has also spread and it has became a pronoun of porcelain also for other purposes.
Along with the spread of the tea drinking habit, the word 'chawan' has also spread and it has become a pronoun for porcelain used for other purposes also.
Along with the spread of the tea drinking habit, the word 'chawan' has also spread and it has become a pronoun for porcelain used for other purposes also.

sen.j: 江戸時代には、素焼の土器や木椀に代わって磁器の食器が使われるようになり、「飯茶碗（蓋付碗）」、「煎茶碗」などの言葉も生まれた。
sen.e: In the Edo period, in pace of unglazed earthenware and wooden bowls, porcelain bowls came into use and consequently the words 'meshijawan' (bowl for rice with lid), 'senchawan' (bowl for green tea) were created.

In the Edo period, during the pace of unglazed earthenware and wooden bowls, porcelain bowls came into use and consequently the words 'meshijawan' (bowl for rice with lid), 'senchawan' (bowl for green tea) were created.

In the Edo period, during the pace of unglazed earthenware and wooden bowls, porcelain bowls came into use and consequently the words 'meshijawan' (bowl for rice with lid), 'senchawan' (bowl for green tea) were created.

sen.j: 現代日本では通常、「お茶碗」と言った場合、飯茶碗を指す。
sen.e: Now in Japan, normally 'ochawan' means meshijawan.
Now in Japan, normally 'ochawan' means meshijawan.
Now in Japan, normally 'ochawan' means meshijawan.

sen.j: 概要
sen.e: Summary
Summary
Summary

sen.j: 茶碗は、その名のとおり茶を飲むための器であり、湯呑み（ゆのみ）や湯呑茶碗（ゆのみちゃわん）とも呼ばれる。
sen.e: As its name suggests, chawan is a bowl to drink tea and also called yunomi (drinking hot water) or yunomichawan (bowl for drinking hot water).
As its name suggests, chawan is a bowl for drinking tea and also called yunomi (drinking hot water) or yunomichawan (bowl for drinking hot water).
As its name suggests, chawan is a bowl for drinking tea and also called yunomi (drinking hot water) or yunomichawan (bowl for drinking hot water).

sen.j: 茶器の一つとして中国か朝鮮で生まれて、奈良時代から平安時代をかけて茶と一緒に日本に伝来したと考えられている。
sen.e: It is thought that it was created as a part of tea set in China or Korea and brought to Japan with tea from the Nara period until the Heian period.
It is thought that it was created as a part of a tea set in China or Korea and brought to Japan with tea from the Nara period until the Heian period.
It is thought that it was created as a part of a tea set in China or Korea and brought to Japan with tea from the Nara period until the Heian period.

sen.j: 日本ではご飯をよそうための椀を特に ご飯茶碗（ごはんちゃわん） や 茶碗（ちゃわん）、飯碗と呼ぶ。
sen.e: In Japan a bowl for rice is specially called 'gohanjawan' 'chawan' or 'meshiwan'.
In Japan a bowl for rice is specially called 'gohanjawan' 'chawan' or 'meshiwan'.
In Japan a bowl for rice is specially called 'gohanjawan' 'chawan' or 'meshiwan.'

sen.j: 日本の家庭での茶碗は湯呑茶碗でもご飯茶碗でも、箸と同様に属人器である。
sen.e: In Japanese homes, whatever it is yunomijawan or gohanjawan, each person has his/her own chawans as well as chop sticks.
In Japanese homes, whether it is yunomijawan or gohanjawan, each person has his or her own set of chawans as well as chop sticks.
In Japanese homes, whether it is yunomijawan or gohanjawan, each person has his or her own set of chawans as well as chop sticks.

sen.j: 古来から多くの家庭で、各人専用の湯呑茶碗とご飯茶碗が定められている。
sen.e: Since old times, in many homes each person has yunomijawan and gohanjawan for private use.
Since old times, in many homes each person has yunomijawan and gohanjawan for private use.
Since old times, in many homes each person has yunomijawan and gohanjawan for private use.

sen.j: ヨーロッパでは、茶碗に相当するものはカップと呼ばれるものである。
sen.e: Chawan is equivalent to cup in Europe.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Chawan is equivalent to a cup in Europe.
Chawan is equivalent to a cup in Europe.

sen.j: 東アジアから喫茶の習慣が伝わった当初は、把手のないカップが主流であったが、次第に把手付きのものが増え、やがてこれが普通となった。
sen.e: When the habit of drinking tea was brought from East Asia, the cups were normally without handles, but gradually those with handles have spread and become common.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: When the habit of drinking tea was brought from East Asia, the cups were normally without handles, but gradually cups with handles have spread and become common.
When the habit of drinking tea was brought from East Asia, the cups were normally without handles, but gradually cups with handles have spread and become common.

sen.j: 英語では把手のないものを tea bowl, 把手のあるものをTeacupと呼び分ける。
sen.e: In English a cup without handle is called tea bowl and one with handle is called tea cup.
In English, a cup without a handle is called a tea bowl and one with handle is called a tea cup.
In English, a cup without a handle is called a tea bowl and one with handle is called a tea cup.

sen.j: Cupはその後更にビュートシェイプ、ピオニーシェイプ、ロンドンシェイプなど様々な形（シェイプ）の変化を生じた。
sen.e: Many variations of cup have been created such as Bute shape, Peony shape, London shape.
Many variations of cups have been created such as the Bute shape, Peony shape, and London shape.
Many variations of cups have been created such as the Bute shape, Peony shape, and London shape.

sen.j: またコーヒー用のカップはコーヒーカップと呼ばれるが、紅茶、コーヒー兼用の形もある。
sen.e: While a cup for coffee is called coffee cup, there are also variations for both tea and coffee.
While a cup for coffee is called a coffee cup, there are also variations in shape for both tea and coffee.
While a cup for coffee is called a coffee cup, there are also variations in shape for both tea and coffee.

sen.j: ヨーロッパでは茶托に当るものはカップソーサーと呼ばれ、カップと同様の材質、デザインで作られ、カップとセットになっているのが普通。
sen.e: A saucer for chawan in Japan is equivalent to a cup saucer in Europe which is made of same material and with same design as cup and normally comes with a cup as a set.
A saucer for chawan in Japan is equivalent to a cup saucer in Europe that is made of the same material and of the same decor as a cup and normally comes with a cup as a set.
A saucer for chawan in Japan is equivalent to a cup saucer in Europe that is made of the same material and of the same decor as a cup and normally comes with a cup as a set.

sen.j: 材質は磁器、または炻器製が圧倒的に多い。
sen.e: Most of them are porcelain or stoneware.
Most of them are porcelain or stoneware.
Most of them are porcelain or stoneware.

sen.j: また米飯用の食器はrice bowlと呼ばれる。
sen.e: Also a bowl for eating rice is called rice bowl.
Also a bowl for eating rice is called a rice bowl.
Also a bowl for eating rice is called a rice bowl.

sen.j: 茶道具としての茶碗
sen.e: Chawan as an utensil for the tea ceremony
Chawan as a utensil for used for tea ceremonies
Chawan as a utensil for used for tea ceremonies

sen.j: 日本の茶道では、季節や趣向に応じて様々な茶碗を用いる。
sen.e: re-wrote the sentence
In a tea ceremony in Japan, various chawans are used depending on the season or the theme.
In a tea ceremony in Japan, various chawans are used depending on the season or the theme.

sen.j: 愛好者の間では『一楽、二萩、三唐津』などと言われることもあり、それらは産地や由来、その色形の特徴によって、主に以下のように分類される。
sen.e: Among the devotees it is called "ichi Raku, ni Hagi, san Karatsu" to rank the porcelains classified as below depending on the production area, origin, color and shape.
Among the devotees, it is called "ichi Raku, ni Hagi, san Karatsu" to rank the porcelains classified as below depending on the production area, origin, color and shape.
Among the devotees, it is called "ichi Raku, ni Hagi, san Karatsu" to rank the porcelains classified as below depending on the production area, origin, color and shape.

sen.j: 唐物
sen.e: Karamono (originated in Chaina)
Karamono (originated in China)
Karamono (originated in China)

sen.j: 天目茶碗
sen.e: Tenmoku jawan
Tenmoku jawan
Tenmoku jawan

sen.j: 青磁茶碗（酸化還元によって発色を決め、辰砂の銅で赤くしたものもある。)
sen.e: Seiji chawan (celadon-ware) (colors are generated by oxidation-reduction and some of them are colored in red by copper of cinnabar.)
Seiji chawan (celadon-ware) (colors are generated by oxidation-reduction and some of them are colored in red by copper of cinnabar.)
Seiji chawan (celadon-ware) (colors are generated by oxidation-reduction and some of them are colored in red by copper of cinnabar.)

sen.j: 白磁茶碗
sen.e: Hakuji chawan (white porcelain)
Hakuji chawan (white porcelain)
Hakuji chawan (white porcelain)

sen.j: 高麗茶碗
sen.e: Korai chawan (originated in Korea)
Korai chawan (originated in Korea)
Korai chawan (originated in Korea)

sen.j: 高麗茶碗、井戸茶碗、三島茶碗（文様を押し当ててガラにしたもの）
sen.e: Korai chawan, ido chawan, mishima chawan (patterned by pressing tools)
Korai chawan, ido chawan, and mishima chawan (patterned by pressing tools)
Korai chawan, ido chawan, and mishima chawan (patterned by pressing tools)

sen.j: 和物
sen.e: Wamono (Japanese)
Wamono (Japanese)

sen.j: 楽焼（楽茶碗）黒、赤、白色
sen.e: Raku yaki (raku chawan) black, red, white
Raku yaki (raku chawan) black, red, and white

sen.j: 萩焼
sen.e: Hagi yaki
Hagi yaki

sen.j: 唐津焼
sen.e: Karatsu yaki
Karatsu yaki

sen.j: 志野茶碗、織部茶碗、瀬戸黒茶碗、黄瀬戸茶碗、伯庵茶碗
sen.e: Shino chawan, oribe chawan, setoguro chawan, kiseto chawan, hakuan chawan
Shino chawan, oribe chawan, setoguro chawan, kiseto chawan, and hakuan chawan

sen.j: 青磁器は硬く、逆に楽焼きは軟陶とよばれる。
sen.e: While seiji is hard, raku yaki is called nanto (soft pottery).
While seiji is hard, raku yaki is called nanto (soft pottery).
While seiji is hard, raku yaki is called nanto (soft pottery).

sen.j: 茶碗の形状は、碗形のものが多いが、筒形や平形、輪形（玉形）、半筒、端反、沓形などがある。
sen.e: Most of chawan are wan gata (bowl form), but there are also tsutsu gata (cylindrical from), hira gata (flat form), wa gata or tama gata (round shape), hanzutsu (semi-cylindrical), hazori (upswept rim), kutsugata (shoe-shaped) etc.

Most chawans are wan gata (bowl form), but there are also tsutsu gata (cylindrical from), hira gata (flat form), wa gata or tama gata (round shape), hanzutsu (semi-cylindrical), hazori (upswept rim), kutsugata (shoe-shaped) etc.

Most chawans are wan gata (bowl form), but there are also tsutsu gata (cylindrical from), hira gata (flat form), wa gata or tama gata (round shape), hanzutsu (semi-cylindrical), hazori (upswept rim), kutsugata (shoe-shaped) etc.

sen.j: また、天目形、井戸形のように茶碗の特徴が形状名になっているものもある。
sen.e: Also there are forms of chawan, that were named by the features of chawan's origins such as tenmoku gata, ido gata.
Also there are forms of chawan, that were named after the features of the origin of chawan such as tenmoku gata, and ido gata.
Also there are forms of chawan, that were named after the features of the origin of chawan such as tenmoku gata, and ido gata.

sen.j: 形状から筒茶碗（つつちゃわん）、平茶碗（ひらちゃわん）等と呼ばれる茶碗もある。
sen.e: Some chawans such as tsutsu chawan and hira chawan are so called because of the shape.
Some chawans such as tsutsu chawan and hira chawan are so called because of their shape.
Some chawans such as tsutsu chawan and hira chawan are so called because of their shape.

sen.j: 飲み口が狭く茶が冷めにくい筒茶碗は主に冬向き。
sen.e: Tsutsu chawan is used for winter because it is deep and keeps the tea hot longer.
Tsutsu chawan is used in winter because it is deep and keeps the tea hot longer.
Tsutsu chawan is used in winter because it is deep and keeps the tea hot longer.

sen.j: 逆に広く冷めやすい平茶碗は夏向きと使われる。
sen.e: On the other hand, hira chawan is used for summer because it is shallow and allow the tea cool rapidly.
On the other hand, hira chawan is used in summer because it is shallow and allows the tea to cool rapidly.
On the other hand, hira chawan is used in summer because it is shallow and allows the tea to cool rapidly.

sen.j: 楽や高麗井戸は格が高いと言われ、濃茶に使われることが多い。
sen.e: Raku and korai ido are considered as higher rank, therefore they are often used for full-flavored powdered green tea.
Raku and korai ido are considered to be in a higher rank, therefore, they are often used for full-flavored powdered green tea.
Raku and korai ido are considered to be in a higher rank, therefore, they are often used for full-flavored powdered green tea.

sen.j: 茶に合わせて作られた、煎茶碗、抹茶碗と呼ばれる茶碗もある。
sen.e: Also there are chawans for each kind of tea such as senchawan and macchawan.
Also there are chawans for each kind of tea such as senchawan and macchawan.
Also there are chawans for each kind of tea such as senchawan and macchawan.

sen.j: 芸術品、工芸品として取引され、作家名の押し印されたものも多く、個々の茶碗に銘（名前）が付けられたものもある。
sen.e: Chawans are treated as art works and artifacts, many of which have the artist names printed on and some of which have their individual names.
Chawans are treated as works of art and artifacts, many of which have the artist's name printed on them and some of which have been given individual names.
Chawans are treated as works of art and artifacts, many of which have the artist's name printed on them and some of which have been given individual names.

sen.j: 磁器は割れやすい材質なので、現代では食堂など業務用にプラスチック製の茶碗も作られている。
sen.e: Because porcelain is broken easily, commercial plastic chawans are also manufactured for restaurants and others.
Because porcelain breaks easily, commercial plastic chawans are also being manufactured for restaurants and so on.
Because porcelain breaks easily, commercial plastic chawans are also being manufactured for restaurants and so on.
